00058 /**
00059  * \ingroup DataTypes
00060  * \brief  Possible verbosity levels
00061  *
00062  * \description
00063  *
00064  *    Generally, error messages are for conditions that halt execution 
00065  *    (e.g. "Error: cannot operate on NULL input"); warning messages 
00066  *    are for unexpected conditions that can still be handled (e.g. "Warning:
00067  *    expected 1 input but found 3, using first one"); log messages are for
00068  *    normal events (e.g. "Log: Variable 'temp' created"); and debug messages 
00069  *    report state, internal variables and other details for developers 
00070  *    (e.g. "Debug: 12 entries in DsTable").
00071  *
00072  *    In FCLib, a verbosity level implies all levels below it. For instance,
00073  *    asking for warning message will also report error messages. The message 
00074  *    hierarchy, from less to more verbose, is:
00075  * 
00076  *    FC_QUIET < FC_ERROR_MESSAGES < FC_WARNING_MESSAGES < FC_LOG_MESSAGES < 
00077  *    FC_DEBUG_MESSAGES
00078  */
00079 typedef enum 
00080 {
00081   FC_QUIET = 0,        /**< no messages */
00082   FC_ERROR_MESSAGES,   /**< error messages   */
00083   FC_WARNING_MESSAGES, /**< warning and error messages */
00084   FC_LOG_MESSAGES,     /**< log, warning and error messages  */ 
00085   FC_DEBUG_MESSAGES    /**< debug, log, warning and error messages */
00086 } FC_VerbosityLevel;     
00087 
00088 /**
00089  * \ingroup  DataTypes
00090  * \brief Possible function return values
00091  *
00092  * \description
00093  * 
00094  *   Enumerated constants are provided for return values. Generally,
00095  *   a function which returns '0' or 'FC_SUCCESS' is considered to
00096  *   have succeeded, and return values less than 1 indicates that
00097  *   an error occurred. FC_ERROR (-1) is a generic error category.
00098  *
00099  * \modifications 
00100  *    - 2003-SEP-22  W Koegler  Created
00101  */
00102 typedef enum 
00103 {
00104   FC_SUCCESS = 0,
00105   FC_ERROR = -1,
00106   FC_MEMORY_ERROR = -2,
00107   FC_INPUT_ERROR = -3,
00108   FC_FILE_IO_ERROR = -4
00109 } FC_ReturnCode;
00110 
00111 /**
00112  * \ingroup   DataTypes
00113  * \brief Possible element types
00114  *
00115  * \description
00116  */
00117 typedef enum 
00118 {
00119   FC_ET_UNKNOWN = 0,
00120   FC_ET_POINT, 
00121   FC_ET_LINE, 
00122   FC_ET_TRI, 
00123   FC_ET_QUAD, 
00124   FC_ET_TET, 
00125   FC_ET_PYRAMID,
00126   FC_ET_PRISM, 
00127   FC_ET_HEX,
00128   // arbitrary polygon?
00129   FC_ET_MIXED /**< This is needed to describe faces on pyramids & prisms */
00130 } FC_ElementType;
00131 
00132 /**
00133  * \ingroup   DataTypes
00134  * \brief Possible data types.
00135  */
00136 typedef enum 
00137 {
00138   FC_DT_UNKNOWN = 0,
00139   FC_DT_CHAR, 
00140   // FC_DT_UCHAR,   
00141   // FC_DT_SHORT, 
00142   // FC_DT_USHORT,
00143   FC_DT_INT, 
00144   // FC_DT_UINT,     
00145   // FC_DT_LONG, 
00146   // FC_DT_ULONG,
00147   // FC_DT_LONGLONG,    /* 64 bits */
00148   // FC_DT_ULONGLONG,   /* 64 bits */
00149   FC_DT_FLOAT, 
00150   FC_DT_DOUBLE 
00151   // FC_DT_LONGDOUBLE,  /* 128 bits */
00152 } FC_DataType;
00153 
00154 /**
00155  * \ingroup   DataTypes
00156  * \brief Possible ways of organizing data values.
00157  *
00158  * \description
00159  * 
00160  *    Specifies the organization and order of the components of a
00161  *    variable. For instance, FC_MT_SCALAR denotes a scalar
00162  *    field which will have a single value per data point.
00163  *    FC_MT_VECTOR denotes a vector field with n (numComponent)
00164  *    ordered components such as X, Y and Z for a vector
00165  *    with 3 components.
00166  */
00167 typedef enum 
00168 {
00169   FC_MT_UNKNOWN = 0,
00170   FC_MT_SCALAR, 
00171   FC_MT_VECTOR, 
00172   FC_MT_SYMTENSOR,  /**< not fully supported by most library routines */
00173   FC_MT_TENSOR      /**< not fully supported by most library routines */
00174 } FC_MathType;
00175 
00176 /**
00177  * \ingroup   DataTypes
00178  * \brief Possible association of the data to the mesh
00179  *
00180  * \description
00181  * 
00182  *     Specifies which type of sub-entity of a mesh something is
00183  *     associated with. E.g a variable with a vertex association
00184  *     will have data for each vertex.
00185  *
00186  * \todo ?Surely we can come up with a better name? entity type?
00187  */
00188 typedef enum 
00189 {
00190   FC_AT_UNKNOWN = 0,
00191   FC_AT_VERTEX, 
00192   FC_AT_EDGE,      /**< Cannot exist in 0D meshes, and is the same
00193               as elements in 1D meshes */
00194   FC_AT_FACE,      /**< Cannot exist in 0D or 1D meshes, and is the
00195               same as elements in 2D meshes */
00196   FC_AT_ELEMENT,   /**< Will be 0D, 1D, 2D or 3D depending on element type */
00197   FC_AT_WHOLE_MESH,    /**< Refers to the entire mesh */
00198   FC_AT_WHOLE_DATASET  /**< Refers to the entire dataset */
00199 } FC_AssociationType;
00200 
00201 //@}

00205 int fc_isReturnCodeValid(FC_ReturnCode rc);

00207 int fc_isDataTypeValid(FC_DataType datatype);
00208 int fc_isMathTypeValid(FC_MathType mathtype);
00209 int fc_isAssociationTypeValid(FC_AssociationType assoc);

00231 /**
00232  * \ingroup  Handles
00233  * \brief Dataset Handle.
00234  *
00235  * \description
00236  * 
00237  *    Handle used by library routines to refer to a specific dataset.
00238  *    See \ref Dataset for functions.
00239  */
00240 typedef struct {
00241     int slotID;    /**< Index into the dataset table. */
00242     int uID;       /**< Unique identifier. */
00243 } FC_Dataset;
00244 
00245 /**
00246  * \ingroup  Handles
00247  * \brief Sequence Handle
00248  *
00249  * \description
00250  * 
00251  *    Handle used by library routines to refer to a specific
00252  *    sequence (e.g. time series). See \ref Sequence for functions. 
00253  */
00254 typedef struct {
00255     int slotID;    /**< Index into the sequence table. */
00256     int uID;       /**< Unique identifier. */
00257 } FC_Sequence;
00258 
00259 /**
00260  * \ingroup  Handles
00261  * \brief Mesh Handle
00262  *
00263  * \description
00264  * 
00265  *    Handle used by library routines to refer to a specific mesh.
00266  *    See \ref Mesh for functions.
00267  */
00268 typedef struct {
00269     int slotID;    /**< Index into the mesh table. */
00270     int uID;       /**< Unique identifier. */
00271 } FC_Mesh;
00272 
00273 /**
00274  * \ingroup  Handles
00275  * \brief Subset Handle
00276  *
00277  * \description
00278  * 
00279  *    Handle used by library routines to refer to a specific subset.
00280  *    See \ref Subset for functions.
00281  *
00282  * \modifications 
00283  *    - 05/11/04 WSK Created.
00284  */
00285 typedef struct {
00286   int slotID;    /**< Index into the subset table. */
00287   int uID;       /**< Unique identifier. */
00288 } FC_Subset;
00289 
00290 /**
00291  * \ingroup  Handles
00292  * \brief Variable Handle
00293  *
00294  * \description
00295  * 
00296  *    Handle used by library routines to refer to a specific
00297  *    variable (or a specific step of a sequence variable, e.g.
00298  *    pressure at time ti). See \ref Variable for functions.
00299  */
00300 typedef struct {
00301     int slotID;    /**< Index into the variable table. */
00302     int uID;       /**< Unique identifier. */
00303 } FC_Variable;
00304 
00305 /** 
00306  * \ingroup  Handles
00307  * \brief  Check two handles for equality
00308  *
00309  * \description
00310  *
00311  *    Evaluates to true (1) if handles are equal, and false(0) 
00312  *    if they are not. Works for all handle types but note
00313  *    that null handles of all types will be equal.
00314  *
00315  * \todo ?NULL handles of different types could have different negative
00316  *       negative sequence numbers to prevent null handles of different
00317  *       types from being equal.
00318  */
00319 #define FC_HANDLE_EQUIV(handle1, handle2) \
00320           (((handle1).slotID == (handle2).slotID) && \
00321           ((handle1).uID == (handle2).uID))
00322 
00323 // "Empty" handles
00324 
00325 extern FC_Dataset FC_NULL_DATASET;
00326 extern FC_Sequence FC_NULL_SEQUENCE;
00327 extern FC_Mesh FC_NULL_MESH;
00328 extern FC_Variable FC_NULL_VARIABLE;
00329 extern FC_Subset FC_NULL_SUBSET;

00331 #ifdef __cplusplus
00332 }
